Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Steps: 1. Calculate the total duration for each case (from the first event to the last event). 2. Identify cases that take significantly longer. We can set a threshold (e.g., based on the mean + 2*std, or by visual inspection) or compare with the majority. Lets compute the duration for each case: Case 2001: Start: 2024-04-01 09:00 End: 2024-04-01 10:30 Duration: 1.5 hours Case 2002: Start: 2024-04-01 09:05 End: 2024-04-02 11:00 Duration: 25 hours 55 minutes (approx 25.92 hours) Case 2003: Start: 2024-04-01 09:10 End: 2024-04-03 09:30 Duration: 48 hours 20 minutes (approx 48.33 hours) Case 2004: Start: 2024-04-01 09:20 End: 2024-04-01 10:45 Duration: 1.42 hours (85 minutes) Case 2005: Start: 2024-04-01 09:25 End: 2024-04-04 14:30 Duration: 3 days 5 hours 5 minutes = 77 hours 5 minutes (approx 77.08 hours)

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Now, we can see that: Case 2001: 1.5 hours Case 2002: ~25.92 hours Case 2003: ~48.33 hours Case 2004: ~1.42 hours Case 2005: ~77.08 hours The cases that are taking significantly longer are 2002, 2003, and 2005. However, note that 2001 and 2004 are very fast (both low complexity and in region A and B respectively, but note 2001 is in A and 2004 in B).

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Lets break down by attributes: Complexity: Low: Cases 2001 (1.5h), 2004 (1.42h) -> both fast. Medium: Case 2002 (25.92h) -> longer. High: Cases 2003 (48.33h), 2005 (77.08h) -> much longer. So, complexity seems to be a factor: medium and high complexity cases take longer.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: But note that in the medium complexity case (2002) we have: Steps: Submit -> Evaluate -> Request Additional Documents -> Approve -> Pay -> Close. The delay seems to be between Evaluate Claim (ends at 09:45 on 2024-04-01) and the next event Request Additional Documents at 14:00 same day (4 hours 15 minutes gap) and then a night and day until next day 10:00 for Approve Claim. In high complexity cases (2003 and 2005), we see multiple Request Additional Documents events and long gaps.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now, lets look at the resources and regions: Case 2001: Region A, Resource: CSR_Jane, Adjuster_Mike, Manager_Ann, Finance_Alan, CSR_Jane -> Low complexity -> fast. Case 2002: Region B, Resource: CSR_Paul, Adjuster_Lisa, Manager_Ann, Finance_Carl, CSR_Paul -> Medium complexity -> 25.92 hours. Case 2003: Region A, Resource: CSR_Jane, Adjuster_Mike, Manager_Bill, Finance_Alan, CSR_Jane -> High complexity -> 48.33 hours. Case 2004: Region B, Resource: CSR_Mary, Adjuster_Lisa, Manager_Ann, Finance_Carl, CSR_Mary -> Low complexity -> fast. Case 2005: Region B, Resource: CSR_Paul, Adjuster_Lisa, Manager_Bill, Finance_Carl, CSR_Paul -> High complexity -> 77.08 hours. We see that: Region A: Case 2001 (Low): fast (1.5h) Case 2003 (High): slow (48.33h) Region B: Case 2002 (Medium): slow (25.92h) Case 2004 (Low): fast (1.42h) Case 2005 (High): very slow (77.08h) So, both regions have fast and slow cases, but the slow cases are associated with higher complexity.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: However, note that in Region A, the high complexity case (2003) took 48.33 hours, while in Region B the high complexity case (2005) took 77.08 hours. So within high complexity, Region B is slower. Also, note the resources: Adjuster_Lisa is handling: Case 2002 (Medium) and Case 2005 (High) in Region B -> both are slow. Adjuster_Mike is handling: Case 2001 (Low) in Region A -> fast, and Case 2003 (High) in Region A -> slow.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now, lets look at the specific delays in the process: For Case 2002 (Medium, Region B, Adjuster_Lisa): After Evaluate Claim (ends at 09:45 on 2024-04-01) -> next event is Request Additional Documents at 14:00 same day (gap: 4h15m). Then from Request Additional Documents (ends at 14:00) to next event (Approve Claim) is 20 hours (until next day 10:00). For Case 2003 (High, Region A, Adjuster_Mike): After Evaluate Claim (ends at 09:40 on 2024-04-01) -> next event is Request Additional Documents at 11:00 (gap: 1h20m). Then next Request Additional Documents at 17:00 same day (gap: 6h). Then gap until next day 16:00 (Approve Claim) -> 23 hours. Then gap until next day 09:00 (Pay Claim) -> 17 hours. For Case 2005 (High, Region B, Adjuster_Lisa): After Evaluate Claim (ends at 09:50 on 2024-04-01) -> next event Request Additional Documents at 11:30 (gap: 1h40m). Then next at 17:00 same day (gap: 5h30m). Then next at 15:00 next day (gap: 22 hours). Then gap until next day 10:00 (Approve Claim) -> 19 hours. Then gap until 14:00 same day (4 hours). We see that the delays occur mainly in the Request Additional Documents phase and the subsequent waiting until the next event.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Now, lets see the number of Request Additional Documents events per case: Case 2001: 0 Case 2002: 1 Case 2003: 2 (two events: at 11:00 and 17:00 on 2024-04-01) Case 2005: 3 (at 11:30, 17:00 on 2024-04-01, and 15:00 on 2024-04-02) So the more requests, the longer the case?

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Root cause analysis: 1. Complexity: - High complexity cases require more requests for additional documents (as seen in 2003 and 2005) and hence take longer. - Medium complexity may require at least one request (2002) and also take longer than low. 2. Region: ... 3. Resource: ... Proposed root causes: 1. Complexity level is a major factor: high complexity claims take longer because they require more requests for additional documents and more time for approval (after the last request).

Name: Validation - PE
Text: This suggests that the approval step is causing a delay of about a day? But note that in low complexity cases, there is no request and the approval is quick (within 30 minutes to 1 hour after evaluation). Therefore, the root cause might be: - The process for medium and high complexity cases requires additional steps (requests) and then the approval step is taking a long time (about a day) after the last request.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Why is the approval taking so long? It could be that the managers are not available immediately? Or they have a backlog? Also, note the region: Region B seems to have a higher number of requests per case? ... The approval step after the last request is consistently taking about 19-23 hours, which might be due to a batch process or manager availability?

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: The log only has one timestamp per event. We assume it is the time the event occurred (and we use the order to compute gaps). But note: the activity might take time? We dont have the duration of the activity? Only the timestamp. So we have to assume that the timestamp is the time the activity was started? Or completed? The problem does not specify. In process mining, event logs often record the timestamp of the event (which can be start or complete). But without more information, we use the timestamps as given and compute the time between consecutive events in the same case.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Given the above, the root causes: - High complexity claims require more requests (multiple) and hence more waiting time for customer responses? - The approval step after the last request is taking a long time (about a day) because of manager unavailability or a batch process? - Adjuster_Lisa might be overburdened? Because she handled two slow cases? - Region B: the high complexity case (2005) took the longest?
